div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION. ----- IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF 76 HINDOO ALIENS. ----- BRIEF.
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH. Merchants Printing Co., Times Bldg., Seattle
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Unlawful Detention of Seventy-Six Hindoos. : : : No. 2532
MEMORANDUM BRIEF OF RESPONDENT. . . . . . . . . . .
The rule applicable.

We rely upon the decisions of the Supreme Court, cited below, as establishing the following propositions, and respectfully urge that if any case cited by petitioners contravenes these doctrines, it is overruled and superseded by the decisions of the Supreme Court. We contend the rule to be as follows:
Right to deport on ground that alien was likely to become a public charge at time of entry.

Section 2 of the Immigration Law forbids the entry of any alien "likely to become a public charge". Sections 20 and 21 provide for the deportation of any alien "who shall enter the United States in violation of law, and such as become public charges from causes existing prior to landing." I am aware of no decision questioning the authority of the Secretary of Labor to deport under these Sections any alien who was "likely" to become a public charge at time of entry", whether they had yet actually become a public charge or not. So often is this procedure adopted by the Department, as appears by the record in this case, has found it necessary to adopt the code word "liken" as an abbreviation of the phrase "likely to become a public charge at time of entry". In the Japanese Immigrant Case, 189 U.S. 86, it appeared that the immigrant had been formally admitted several days prior to her arrest and deportation. There was nothing to show that she had actually become a public charge in the meanwhile. Nevertheless she was arrested and deported under the same procedure followed in this case, as "a pauper and person likley to become a public charge", not one who had become a public charge. Had she been deportated as an alien seeking admission into the United States, the procedure would have been entirely different (See Sections 24 and 25). It can make no difference as to the legal right of the Secretary to deport under this charge, that the time elapsed in the case just cited was only a few days. The
alien in such case was in the country and if to be deported at all it had to be under the provisions of the law looking to the deportation of an alien already in the country. Section 11 of the Act of 1891 (Stat. at Large Vol. 26, pp. 1084, 1085) contained very similar provisions to section 20 of the present act, so the case is directly applicable to the present case and is direct authority for the practice of the department to deport aliens as "likely to become a public charge at time of entry", even though they have not actually become public charges.

So also in United States v. Freeman, 175 Fed. 274, while other matters were alleged, the decision of the court sustaining the deportation of an alien already in the United States under the procedure outlined by Sections 20 and 21, was based upon the fact the aline was "likely to become a public charge at time of entry". And indeed if such is the fact, the alien is undoubtedly in the United States "In violation of law" and there would no reason why the government should wait to until the danger has developed into an actual happening. The insertion of the clause as to those who do become public charges was doubtless meant to meet cases where it could not be said that there was any likelyhood of becoming a public charge at time of entry, but where such a condition does nevertheless develop from circumstances existing at the time of entry.

The cases cited by petitioner in support of his contention that Section 20 does not authorize deportation within three years on the charge of liability to become a public charge at time of entry are all beside the mark. Gonzales v. Williams, 192 U.S. 1, merely determines the status of one who was a native of Porto Rico prior to its acquisition by the United States. Sprung v. Morton, 182 Fed. 330, Ex parte Saraceno, 182 Fed. 955, Lewis v. Frick, 189 Fed. 146, United States v. Tsuji Suekichi, 199 Fed. 750, all relate to the right of aliens who had been domiciled in this country for over three years, and who were seeking to return here after a temporary absence. The holding that the immigration law does not apply to them on their reentry, has obviously no bearing on the correct interpertation of Section 20 explicitly authorizing deportation for illegal entry (including original liability to become a public charge) at any time within three years from the date of the original entry.
The Cedula or Head Tax and other documentary evidence touching entry or residence in Manilla.

At the time of drawing up the return, and until just before argument, I did not have an opportunity to examine the warrants of the Secretary ordering deportation, and therefore placed an undue emphasis on the charge of an original entry into the Philippines without examination. The final warrants of deportation, on which the aliens are now held, show that the Secretary did not base his ruling upon this, but upon the liability to become a public charge at time of entry. Thus the question as to examination at that time is of minor importance and if they were examined it is only entitled to such weight as it may carry as tending to show that at such time they were not likely to become public charges. Nevertheless the presumption arising from the absence of the certificate still holds, and in every instance the Secretary was entitled to consider this absence as a circumstance tending to show an irregular entry and hence doing away with any favorable presumption as to earning ability which might arise from a regular entry.

I have been unable to secure a copy of the local laws government this matter, but by a conversation with Frank A. Greene, Esq., an attorney of this city , who practiced for several years in the Philippines, and who was connected with the War Department which had charge of the collection of this tax, I am informed that this was a tax levied on every male person, having no connection by law with the entry or regularity of the entry of the person into the Islands. This being true, I do not think this court has any
further concern with the matter. Its collection was not by the immigration service and any custom which may have grownn up by which those collecting it accepted a certificate of the immigration officers as proof of the period of residence of an alien paying the tax was a matter of evidence which respondents failed to present to the Department at the time of hearing and of which they certainly cannot avail themselves at this hearing. But as Your Honor asked for information at that point, I will say that as nearly as I can ascertain, there did exist in Manilla, even prior to the promulgation of Rule 14 of the Rules, November 1911 (See p. 32), a custom of giving an alien on landing an informal certificate, and that the collecters of the cedula or internal revenue head tax, would often ask an alien for this certificate at the time of collecting the head tax in order to ascertain for how long a period they should collect the head tax. But Mr. Green informs me that any one whatsoever could get a cedula or head tax receipt by paying for the same.

This tax which applies to every one in the Philippines and is confined to the Philippines is of course to be carefully distinguished from the head tax imposed by Section 1 of the Immigration Act, which is in a different amount imposed on all aliens entering the United States, is a alien on the vessel bringing in the alien, and which as a matter of fact is generally paid to the Government in a lump sum by the transportation company.

Attached to petitioners' brief presented to this court are various documents tending more or less clearly to show
that the aliens referred to therein had been before the immigration authorities at Manilla. Similar documents are contained in the affidavits which he forwarded to the Secretary at Washington. They are also referred to, though not set out at length in the transcript of the evidence which was forwarded to Washington. It must therefore be assumed that they were given what weight they were entitled to in reaching the decision of the Secretary. But as noted before this whole question is of minor importance in view of the fact that the warrants of deportation did not give clandestine entry as their basis, but liability to become a public charge at time of entry.
The evidence.

While the ultimate decision in this matter was made by the Secretary of Labor from the transcript of the evidence and proceedings at the Seattle hearings, and from the affidavits contained in the brief of the petitioners addressed to the Secretary, yet there is in the record a resume of the evidence from the standpoint of the Commissiner, which resume was transmitted to the Secretary, and which is borne out by the transcript of the actual evidence heard. This resume does not of course contain or refer to all the evidence, but for the purposes of Your Honor at the present time this is not necessary. It does show all that need be shown, to-wit: that there was some evidence that each one of these Hindus at the time of his entry into the United States (the Philippine Islands) was likely to become a public charge. There having been a
hearing and an opportunity for the petitioners to be heard and to present their evidence, and some evidence, however slight, having been introduced in support of the ruling of the Secretary of Labor, the matter is settled and the writ of habeas corpus will not issue out of this court, any more than it would to review a conviction and sentence of a state court in a matter in which it had jurisdiction. Under the decisions of the Supreme Court, the hearing before the Secretary is as much due process of law, as the hearing before any court.
Respectfully submitted,
C.F. Riddell United States Attorney.
E B Brockway
